response.answer_text: I like this question. First, I’d point out that the need for speedy handwriting has virtually disappeared from most Chinese people’s everyday life - at least, Chinese people of my generation. With rare exceptions, typing on a keyboard or a mobile device is how we need to put something into “writing” nowadays. When we do need to write, the answer to this question depends on HOW you write. The short answer is that, writing out each character the exact way you see it in print is very slow, but most people don’t do it that way. There are three styles of Chinese writing that are commonly learned and used by Chinese when we hand-write.  (1) 楷书 (kǎi shū), or standard style. This is what everyone learns as pupils of the language. It takes about four to six years of formal schooling to master the first 3000 or so characters, at which point one is considered literate. Up to this point, you only learn to write in this style. Although it helps with the mastery of radicals and formations of each character, it is painfully slow! You can’t possibly write fast because each stroke is separate from another. This means you lift the tip of your pen when you finish one stroke, and move it to a new stroke, something very time-consuming no matter how proficient you are. The sentence in the picture above, 我是中国人 (I am a Chinese), has five characters containing 31 strokes. (2) 行书 (xíng shū), or walking style. This is a much faster, and much better-looking style in my opinion. It allows for much smoother transitions between stokes because the tip of the pen doesn’t necessarily leave the paper between strokes. Most people use some variation of the walking style. It speeds up the writing, but the writing would be still legible for the most part. (3) 草书 (cǎo shū), or running style. If you have to read others’ writing every day (I hate it when I have to), this is your nightmare. It is faster than the walking style, but if poorly written, the characters can be extremely difficult to identify. In the spirit of scientific experiment, I just did some quick tests on myself. When I type Chinese using Sogou Pinyin (搜狗拼音) input method, I can be up to 90 characters per minute. The test I used was 在线打字测试（dazi.kukuw.com） On a smartphone, I guess my speed would be roughly 40 to 60 words per minute (didn’t do an experiment to test this one though). Our typing speed also depends on the material: clear sentence structures and basic vocabulary would allow for more accurate predictions of characters, saving the time otherwise spent on manually selecting characters. I then tried hand-writing the same text in the walking style, and finished exactly 40 characters in one minute. Not bad! But given how ugly it looks, it’s probably not something that I’m comfortable submitting to my boss.

I feel like Chinese (characters) is “zipped/encoded” information. A lot of information is passed by assuming reader and writer know the context of the express (zip/unzip method). e.g. Chinese history, Chinese idiom, or populate things happening now. English also have some zipped expression, but not frequently used as Chinese. (may have bias due to limited knowledge of English) So simply comparing the writing speed to express same information may be somehow unfair for English. Communicate in Chinese is like zip information (use brain/cpu), write it (hand/IO), read it (eye/IO), and unzip (use brain/cpu) it. Maybe the limit of IO (human writing speed) is similar. The total time spend on passing zipped data (Chinese) will be quicker then passing raw data (English). The disadvantage of Chinese is the zip/unzip need prerequisite knowledge: generally feeling about characters (zip/unzip method) and context knowledge like idiom or newly coined word (expression mapping). If the context (expression mapping) is unknown for a particular expression, it will take extra time to learn it (load it in to the mapping table) at the first time and next time will pick it up from memory (cache). If prerequisite knowledge is not available, Chinese will try to interpret it with generic feeling and existing knowledge, and sometime it could be wrong. e.g. “空穴来风”(kongxuelaifeng, lit. wind from an empty cave.) It means something have a reason, or is real. the context is “wind can be felt near cave/tunnel since the wind is be strengthen by it, so the cave is the reason of the wind”. but if people interpret it with generic feeling, “empty cave”, “wind” will interpret it as rumor, something not real. Interestingly, even if it’s miss used people usually still can understand the writer’s meaning according to context.

This is a very good question which could be easily expanded in to a full-length study of the cost/efficiency analysis on the hand movement in order to express the same amount of information in different languages. And it could also be considered as some kind of study on the coding efficiency. But back to the original question, there is a criteria which is very blurry: On what standard would you consider that the speed of the writing are the same? And they are writing what kind of manuscripts? Since if you just give some random single word or very simple sentences, then the two languages are almost the same when comparing the writing speed, providing that those who take the tests have the equivalent language training and same amount of schooling in their own languages. However, if we are talking about “expressing the same idea with their own language”, then the harder and more complicated the idea is, the more advantage the Chinese kid has. Since the rules to combine Chinese single characters or short words to forming new words in order to express very complicated ideas are far more flexible and easier than the English can manage. And here is a very amusing piece of evidence to prove my point: Blizzard Permanently Banned 1572 players in China. • /r/Overwatch the simple sum up of this post is: "User names can only be 6-12 characters long" Chinese: Alright, time to write a story. So even when the writing speed of a single word/character could be the same, when it comes to complicated manuscripts, the Chinese language would easily dominate the speed competition.

There are many Chinese handwritten scripts to help you write faster. The 宋体 typeface, the standard typeface in printing, is probably the Chinese characters you have seen, but this typeface is only used in printing, never in handwriting. Therefore it is not a script. It is only a typeface. The 楷书 script, the regular script, is the official standard handwritten script. It is not used not only in handwriting, but also in printing. However, almost only Chinese kids write like this. Chinese adults hardly ever write like this, because it is too time-consuming. Some calligraphers may also write like this, as an art of calligraphy. The 行书 script, the semi-cursive script, is widely used by Chinese adults. I also write like this. Almost every native Chinese speaker can understand this script. The 草书 script, the cursive script, is sometimes used by shorthand. [Note: 草 means 潦草 (scribbled) here, not “grass”.] Some calligraphers may also write like this as an art of calligraphy. It is written really fast and therefore very few people can understand this scribble. As a native Chinese speaker, I have great difficulty in understanding this script.

Stroke wise, yes, it’s not slower or faster. Pretty much the same. Wordwise, well… maybe you can write longer and more words in english than an average person does in chinese. But then again because of the nature of Chinese language, usually it will take around 50 or 60% less characters to finish the same sentence. As in, 140 characters in a tweet might suffice for a short sentence or two, whereas 140 chinese characters can tell you a short story (or maybe 2!). The summarizing power of chinese characters is amazing. So, concerning each letter, well, yeah, of course it usually takes longer write a hanzi than to write an “a”, a “b” or a “C”, but if you count the total number of strokes in a sentence you’ll be amazed that using the same stroke speed for both languages, it’s faster in chinese. Compare: I’m hungry *(Roughly 15 strokes, depending on how you write it) ” with chinese “我饿了” 19 strokes. Again, strokewise similar, but 3 characters vs 10 in english. And another one:西东南北 = 4 chars, 25 strokes West East South North = 21 chars (spaces DO count), around 30 strokes (again, depends on how you tipe, cursive or not, caps or not. But you get the idea. So yeah, usually writing in chinese it’s a bit faster, you save space, and you can compress your thoughts and take notes or jot down stuff as fast as any other language. In traditional chinese the tradeoff is not as-effective, but still, when we write for ourselves, we simplify strokes and draw lines faster, so it becomes even faster.

I can write and text much faster in Chinese than I can in English. This is because I am able to use IME (Input Method Editors) to input Pinyin leading consonants for frequently used phrases. For example, “zmy” can be entered to get 怎么样. (zen3 me5 yang4), which means “how about that?” or similar. A common phrase that takes 4 keystrokes maximum, three typically, because I can simply go on to the next word if the offered Chinese characters are the ones I want. Usually that is true. When not true, I have to select a number, typically between 1 and 8, which is the set of Chinese characters I want. Another example, after doing some tree trimming, I wanted to write the characters 砍树 (kan3 shu4), which means trim the tree. However, “ks” will almost always offer 看书 first (kan4 shu1, to read a book), a much more common expression. So, that was three touches instead of 2. Still, these are faster than typing out the English equivalent. Chinese characters may look complicated, but once you understand the structure and usage and typical usage norms, the day to day utility is amazingly high. It *is* an efficient language.
